posts.cooked:
Hello,

Our PathPlanner paths worked around 40% of the time during our competition. While we were tethered it worked most of the time, but sometimes the beginning path which drives a small distance forward will turn to the left instead of going straight from the beginning. We’ve tried a handful of things such as recalibrating our navX with the buttons on the board. Our navX goes through calibration already every time the robot is started through code, we also make sure to reset the encoders/navX on the first trajectory which is recommended in the PathPlanner docs. I haven’t been able to replicate the bug where it turns to the left, it seems to just be random. Sometimes when we put it on the field it followed the path, other times it did the turn.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
It would help to have a link to your code, a video of the robot going wrong, and a screenshot showing what the odometry thinks is happening (e.g. Field2d ).

Without those, it’s hard for us to help you, but some possible causes include motor inversion (say after brownout) and CANcoders with improperly glued magnets.

Sadly, I no longer have access to the robot as we already have shipped it. We were using fully charged batteries for every test and I did not see any brownouts. We use the NEO motor’s built-in encoders. We’ve tried the REV through-bore encoders but could not get the FRC system identification to work with them. I did check the logs after each of our matches and did notice that sometimes when the autonomous didn’t follow the path, during the autonomous period we would draw a lot more current compared to when it worked on the practice field. However, when we noticed that we re-used the same battery that the path worked at the practice field for our match and the robot didn’t follow the path.

Here is our drive code:

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
raspb3rry314:

draw a lot more current compared to when it worked on the practice field. However, when we noticed that we re-used the same battery

Are you saying that the path was followed in practice but then in competition, immediately after that practice session and without recharging the battery, the robot didn’t follow the practice?

That’s a depleted battery. And setting a voltage compensation level for any autonomous functions even with a fully charged battery can improve the reproducibility of the autonomous.

posts.name: Basel Alghanem
posts.cooked: Is it just a brief veer and then it follows the path properly? If yes, it could be that when you start the path, your wheels are initially aligned sideways instead of forwards. You can make sure your wheels are forward before starting the path.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
raspb3rry314:

Sadly, I no longer have access to the robot as we already have shipped it

Do you have the driver station?  Can you share ds logs?

I don’t reccommend calibrating it at the beginning of every match because this could cause issues if it is powered on while moving, the reset function also takes a while to complete too so I would apply the offset after you fetch angles from it.

No, we noticed that on the field the autonomous drew more current than it does on the practice field. So we grabbed a fully charged battery and tried the autonomous once on the practice field and it worked so we turned it off and used the exact same battery during the match. The autonomous did not follow the path during the match.
No, instead of going straight the robot curves to the left. We placed the robot pretty straight on the field, we aren’t using swerve.

Sadly I don’t have that either, but I do remember the logs. When the autonomous was working, the current draw started a bit above 12 volts, and at the most, it would go down to around 10 volts. When the autonomous didn’t work it would go from 12 volts down to 7 volts. We’ve tried using different batteries all fully charged, but sometimes the autonomous would work and sometimes it didn’t. We made a list of what batteries the autonomous would work with and took it to the practice field we kept running the autonomous and it would be okay, but once we get to the field for our match it wouldn’t follow the path and just turn.
We thought the calibration was the issue too, but we had a routine of not turning on the robot until it is in the correct position for autonomous, and after we turned it on, we would not touch it.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Our favorite Bear (he’s posting herein) and other teams make robust code for checking for successful device configurations and other commands instead of hoping for the best. I copied the spirit of their structure to check for configuration errors and retry on error - an example starts here . Rarely do motor related commands fail but if they do they’ll drive you crazy and I like to know about them. It’s a hard discipline to do - error checking can consume the bulk of a program and makes the program ugly and harder to read but it should be done. My team still won’t do it.

In a similar but different vein, add a lot of outputs to a log. WPILib DataLogManager is a good tool to quickly and efficiently track what the robot devices are doing. Throw everything you can to the log and you’ll have it when troubleshooting is needed. Stick a USB flash drive in the roboRIO and DataLog goes to it automatically - easy!

posts.name: Collin
posts.cooked:
Based on this code, I would assume that the path isn’t getting properly mirrored for the correct alliance. To properly invert the path for the red alliance, use this code instead:

Or even better yet, use the RamseteAutoBuilder to also have the ability to include stop points on your path.

I haven’t heard of the data logging, we’ll definitely try it out.

Also, how would we go about adding voltage compensation for our autonomous? I’ve never used it before.
We definitely are using PathPlanners mirroring in the RamseteCommand

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
raspb3rry314:

compensation for our autonomous

This was most valuable when so many autonomous paths were based on timing and not any other feedback mechanism that could keep the robot on plan. Still, I’d put in at least a small value, say 12 (volts), to make the routines a little more predictable with different batteries. Give it a try if you have the time to experiment. More aggressive, say 11 or 10, might not be bad. You’d have to try it and see (I don’t want to be leading you astray).

An example is in the link I posted. I hope the other suggestions posted by other path experts work out for you.

posts.name: Collin
posts.cooked: How are you setting the initial pose then? Because in PPRamseteCommand, when you use the alliance switching, it doesn’t transform your initial pose. So you should maybe debug in the simulator and see where your robot is placed on the Field to see if the robot will properly transform the initial pose for the correct alliance.

I see, I didn’t know the PPRameseteCommand didn’t handle transforming the initial pose. However, we had no problems being on the red or blue alliance. Our paths worked for both alliances but as stated before it sometimes would veer off the initial path and this happened on both alliances, not just one.
